 JUDGMENT

 The plaintiffs have filed this suit for partition of the suit

schedule properties by metes and bounds and allotting them

their legitimate half share in the suit schedule properties and

put them in separate possession of their respective half share,

for mesne profits from the date of suit till delivery of

possession of their respective legitimate share in the suit

schedule properties, to award costs of the suit and to pass

such other reliefs.

 5 OS No.5985/1988

 2. The suit schedule properties as described in the

plaint is as under:-

 SCHEDULE

 1) All that piece and parcel of immovable
 property bearing No.225 situated at
 Bellandoor Village, Varthur Hobli,
 Bangalore South Tauk valud at
 Rs.40,000/ bounded on the:

 East by: Road and private property
 West by: Private Property
 North by: Private property
 South by: Road and private property

 2) All that piece and parcel of the immovable
 property bearing Sy.No.61/1, measuring
 1 acre 27 guntas, wet land assessed at
 Rs.2.69 p. situated at Bellandoor Village,
 Varthur Hobli, Bangalore South Taluk on
 the east, west, north and south by private
 properties.

 3) All that piece and parcel of the immovable

 property bearing Sy.No.79/2 measuring 1

 acre 3 guntas, agricultural dry land,
 assessed at Rs.1.59 p Bellandoor Village,
 Varthur Hobli, Bangalore South Taluk on
 the east, west, north and south by private
 properties.

 4) All that piece and parcel of the immovable

 property bearing Sy.No.28/2 measuring 6

 guntas, agricultural wet land, assessed at
 Rs.0.34 p situated at Amani Bellandoor

 6 OS No.5985/1988

 Khane, Varthur Hobli, Bangalore South
 Taluk on the east, west, north and south
 by private properties.

 5) All that piece and parcel of immovable
 property bearing Sy.No.79/3 measuring
 33 guntas, agricultural dry land, assessed
 at Rs.1.24 p. situated at Bellandoor
 Village, Varthur Hobli, Bangalore South
 Taluk on the east, west, north and south
 by private properties.

 6) All that piece and parcel of immovable
 property bearing Sy.No.21/2 measuring
 17 guntas, agricultural wet land, assessed
 at Rs.0.85 p. situated at Kaikandarahalli
 Village, Varthur Hobli, Bangalore South
 Taluk on the east, west, north and south
 by private properties.

 7) All that piece and parcel of the immovable
 property bearing Sy.No.10/7 measuring
 38 guntas, agricultural dry land, assessed
 at Rs.1.31 p. situated at
 Devarabisanahalli, Varthur Hobli,
 Bangalore South Taluk, on the east, west,
 north and south by private properties.

3. The plaint averments in brief are as under:

 The 1st plaintiff is the wife, 2nd and 3rd plaintiffs

are the daughters of late Dodda Abbaiah. The said

Dodda Abbaiah and the defendant No.1 are the direct

 7 OS No.5985/1988

brothers and sons of late Sidda Reddy. The plaintiffs

and the defendants are governed by Hindu Undivided

Joint Family and suit schedule properties are all

ancestral and joint family properties. The said Dodda

Abbaiah died on 28.6.1987 at Bellandur Village leaving

behind the plaintiffs and his rights and interest in the

suit schedule properties. The plaintiffs are the sole

surviving successors to the estate of Late Dodda

Abbaiah.

 The said Dodda Abbaiah and the defendant were

acquired and managing the suit schedule ancestral

undivided joint family properties. After the death of

said Dodda Abbaiah, the defendant alone is managing

the suit schedule properties. During the life time of Late

Dodda Abbaiah, he was very much concerned and

interested to effect the partition and division of the joint

family suit schedule properties between himself and the

defendant. The said Dodda Abbaiah died unexpectedly

 8 OS No.5985/1988

to the surprise of the plaintiffs and relations without

effecting the partition.

 After the death of Dodda Abbaiah the plaintiffs

requested and advised the defendant to have a

settlement and divide the suit schedule properties by

metes and bounds. The defendant refused to effect

partition, but started to enjoy independently as his

own.

 The plaintiffs are also succeeded to the estate of

deceased Dodda Abbaiah, who is entitled to half share

in all the ancestral joint family properties, which were

owned and possessed jointly along with the defendant.

The plaintiffs are entitled to equal shares in the half

share in the joint family suit schedule properties.

 The defendant is now proclaiming that he alone is

entitled to the suit schedule property and making

arrangements to alienate the suit schedule properties

without any notice to the plaintiffs and also making

attempts to change the revenue records and documents

 9 OS No.5985/1988

in his individual names. The defendant refused partition

of the suit schedule properties. The defendant is

depriving the rights of the plaintiffs over the suit

schedule properties.

 The plaintiffs are also issued legal notice dated

13.1.1988 calling upon the defendant to effect partition

in the suit schedule properties by metes and bounds.

The defendant instead of effecting partition, issued an

untenable reply dated 27.1.1988 and thus refused to

effect partition.

 The plaintiffs are legally entitled for half share in

all the suit schedule properties as the plaintiffs are the

surviving successors to the estate of Late Dodda

Abbaiah, who died in the year 1987 leaving behind the

plaintiffs and his half share of estate in the undivided

joint family ancestral suit schedule properties.

 During the pendency of the suit, the defendants

No.1 and 2 have formed sites in the following item Nos.3

 10 OS No.5985/1988

and 5 of the schedule and have sold the same to

defendants No.3 to 6 as detailed hereunder.

 1) The portion of item No.3 bearing Sy.No.79/2
 measuring 1 acre 0.03 guntas

 2) The portion of item No.5 bearing Sy.No.79/3
 measuring 0.33 guntas by for

 3) The 3rd defendant has purchased 4 sites
 under the registered sale deeds dated
 13.3.2006, 15.6.2006, 27.02.2006 and
 14.02.2005

 4) The 4th defendant has purchased the site
 under the registered sale deed dated
 25.8.2005

 5) The 5th defendant has purchased one site
 under the registered sale deed dated
 16.6.2006

 6) The 6th defendant has purchased one site
 under the registered sale deed dated
 5.7.2006

 During the pendency of the suit, portion of the

lands described in item Nos.2, 4, 6 and 7 were acquired

by Karnataka Industrial Area Development Board -

KIADB, Bangalore and part of the matter is the subject

matter of LAC.No.57/2008 and the same is pending

disposal before the CCH No.17. In this regard the

letters written by Spl. LAO, KIADB, Bangalore are as

follows:

 11 OS No.5985/1988

 1) Letter dated 10.11.2005 addressed by the
 Spl. LAO, KIADB, Bangalore to the Registrar,
 City Civil Court, Bangalore

 2) Letter dated 11.04.2008 addressed by the
 Spl. LAO, KIADB, Bangalore to the Prl. City
 Civil Judge, Senior Division, City Civil Court,
 Bangalore District, Bangalore
 Further the details of land acquired is given
hereunder:

 a) The land measuring 0.09 guntas in
 Sy.No.61/1 forming in portion of land
 described in item No.2 of the plaint
 schedule.

 b) Land measuring 0.06 guntas in
 Sy.No.28/2 forming in portion of land
 described in item No.4 of the plaint
 schedule

 c) Land measuring 0.17 guntas in
 Sy.No.21/2 forming in portion of land
 described in item No.6 of the plaint
 schedule

 d) Land measuring 0.38 guntas in
 Sy.No.10/7 forming in portion of land
 described in item No.7 of the plaint
 schedule

 12 OS No.5985/1988

 The amount of compensation payable in respect of

 the aforesaid acquired lands will have to be partitioned

 amongst plaintiffs and those who are entitled to share

 the suit schedule properties. Hence prays to decree the

 suit.

 4. Upon service of summons, the defendant No.1

appeared before the court through his counsel and filed

written statement contending that Late Dodda Abbaiah was

the elder brother of this defendant and 1st plaintiff married

Dodda Abbaiah about 50 years ago, but she did not live with

him for a couple of years as his wife. She deserted and

walked out of the life of Dodda Abbaiah more than 45 years

ago and was openly living with one Kadubisanahally

Narayana Reddy for a few years as his mistress. After some

years she left him and was living at different places and

presently she is living at the address given in the plaint. After

the 1st plaintiff deserted him, Dodda Abbaiah married again

one Chinnamma, who was living with him till she died about

 13 OS No.5985/1988

30 years ago. The Late Dodda Abbaiah did not have any

issue either from the 1st plaintiff or his 2nd wife.

 In as much as they were never born while the 1st

plaintiff was living with Late Dodda Abbaiah in his house or

while she was living with Kadubisanahally Narayana Reddy.

Till today this defendant does not know hen and where the

2nd and 3rd plaintiffs were born to the 1st plaintiff. He admits

that Dodda Abbaiah died on 28.6.1987 at Bellandur Village.

This defendant and his brother Dodda Abbaiah were never

living as members of joint Hindu family and there were no

joint family properties to be shared between them at the time

of death of Dodda Abbaiah as alleged. The suit schedule

properties are in exclusive possession and enjoyment of the

defendant are his own absolute properties, in which late

Dodda Abbaiah had no right, title or interest.

 Late Dodda Abbaiah after the death of his 2nd wife

relinquished his share in the ancestral properties i.e. item

No.2 and 4 to 7 of the suit schedule properties in favour of

this defendant and left village and living in different places for

 14 OS No.5985/1988

a few years. He returned to the village after 20 years ago and

living a life of mendicant and eking out his livelihood by

engaging himself as an agricultural labourer and after

completing 60 years of age he was getting old age pension for

the last 15 years till his death and was maintaining himself

with that pension amount and small helps given by well-

wishers and sympathizers in the village.

a) The suit schedule item No.1 and 3 are the self acquired

 properties of defendant. He purchased the 1st item as

 vacant site from his own funds and built the present house

 thereon from his own funds. Likewise the item No.3 was

 purchased by defendant under sale deed dated 20.8.1964

 from one Venkatappa @ Abbaiah Reddy from his own

 funds. The khatha of all the properties are changed to the

 name of this defendant and he is in possession and

 enjoyment of the same as sole absolute owner thereof.

 15 OS No.5985/1988

 As a matter of fact Late Dodda Abbaiah had given his

consent and no objection for the transfer of khatha in favour

of this defendant in respect of ancestral family properties,

which clearly establish that he had relinquished right if any

he had in the said properties in favour of this defendant.

 That being so the plaintiffs have no legal right to claim

any share in the sole and absolute properties of the

defendant. The 1st plaintiff, who deserted Late Dodda

Abbaiah more than 45 years ago and was leading a

questionable life all these years has no legal right or

competence to claim any share n the alleged estate of Late

Dodda Abbaiah as his legal heir. The 2nd and 3rd plaintiffs are

not the daughters of Late Dodda Abbaiah and therefore they

cannot claim themselves to be the legal heirs of Dodda

Abbaiah much less claim any share in the suit schedule

properties.

 Kate Dodda Abbaiah never demanded for partition and

division of the suit schedule properties at any time claiming

them to be the joint family properties of himself and the

 16 OS No.5985/1988

defendant. No did the plaintiffs demand the defendant after

the death of Dodda Abbaiah to effect division of the suit

schedule properties by metes and bounds. The suit schedule

properties are not the joint family properties of Dodda

Abbaiah and the defendant.

 The defendant got the revenue records and documents

relating to some of the suit schedule properties changed to

his name and is also attempting to change the records and

documents relating to other suit properties to his individual

name. The defendant being the absolute and sole owner of

the suit schedule properties is entitled to exercise his right of

ownership over them in any manner and take steps to

safeguard his title and interest in his properties in the

manner he thinks best and proper. The plaintiffs have locus-

standi or authority to question the said right of exercise of

ownership by the defendant and make a grievance of it.

 It is true that plaintiffs had caused legal notice dated

13.1.1988 issued to the defendant making false and

untenable allegations and the same has been suitably replied.

 17 OS No.5985/1988

The 1st plaintiff deserted and walked out of the life of Dodda

Abbaiah more than 45 years.

 The plaintiffs are not entitled to maintain the suit for

partition as they are not at all the legal heirs of deceased

Dodda Abbaiah and even otherwise Late Dodda Abbaiah

having relinquished his share in the ancestral properties in

favour of defendant more than 30 years ago, from which

period the defendant is in exclusive possession of all the

properties in his own right, exercising right of ownership

openly and uninterruptedly all these years. Items No.1 and 3

are the self acquired properties of defendants and as such the

plaintiffs have no right to claim any share in the said items.

Item No.6 has been sold by the defendant to one

B.Venkataswamy Reddy, son of Pillaiah under registered sale

deed dated 17.9.1984 and said purchaser is in possession of

the said land. The suit is bad for non-joinder of necessary

parties i.e. alinee of item No.6 of the schedule property has

not been made as a party to the suit. Hence, prayed to

dismiss the suit.

 18 OS No.5985/1988

 5. The defendant No.1 died during the pendency of

the suit and thereafter his legal heirs were brought on record

as defendant No.1(a) and 1(b). The defendant No.1(a) and (b)

are also died, and their legal heirs i.e. the defendant No.1(a)(i)

and 1(b)(i) were brought on record, who appeared before the

court through their counsel and filed additional written

statement contending that Chikka Abbaiah had married

Smt.Thimmakka and Smt.Papamma, they were arrayed as

defendant No.1(a) and 1(b). The defendant No.1(a) and 1(b)

during their life time have executed a Will dated 23.12.2009

bequeathing the items No.1 to 3 and 7. The defendant No.1(b)

died on 25.11.2011 and defendant No.1(a) died on 6.10.2013

leaving behind this defendant to succeed to their estate in

terms of Will dated 23.12.2009. In pursuance of the said will

the defendant No.1(a) and (b) have succeeded to the

properties under the will and in possession and enjoyment of

the same and exercising acts of ownership over the said

properties. The plaintiffs were never in possession of any

portion of suit schedule properties at any point of time and as

 19 OS No.5985/1988

such the alleged joint possession is specifically denied as

false. Hence, prayed to dismiss the suit.

 6. The 2nd defendant filed written statement

contending that he is bonafide purchaser of item No.3 of the

suit schedule property under two registered sale deed dated

12.2.1996 and 31.1.1996 for valuable sale consideration. At

the time of purchase, it was represented to him by the 1st

defendant that the property in question is an ancestral

property and brother of Dodda Abbaiah died issueless and

that 1st defendant was the sole surviving male successor to

the property in question. This defendant after verification of

certain facts purchased item No.3 of the suit schedule

property. The present suit is filed for partition of certain

properties against his vendor. He is not aware of any legal

proceedings pending in respect of the properties that he

purchased. Hence, he adopts the written statement filed by

1st defendant. Accordingly, prayed to dismiss the suit.

 20 OS No.5985/1988

 7. The defendant No.3 appeared through his counsel

but did not file his written statement.

 8. Inspite of service of summons, the defendant No.4

not appeared before the court and hence he is placed exparte.

 9. The defendant No.5 appeared through his counsel

but did not file his written statement.

 10. The 6th defendant filed written statement

contending that during the pendency of the suit he came to

know that 1st plaintiff died leaving behind plaintiffs No.2 and

3 as her sole surviving heirs. The plaintiffs No.2 and 3 have

executed two release deeds with respect to the item No.1 and

2 of the written statement schedule properties in favour of

himself and 5th defendant. By virtue of the said release deeds

the dispute between the plaintiff on one hand and 5th

defendant and himself on the other hand stands totally

settled and adjusted in respect of item Nos.1 and 2 of the

 21 OS No.5985/1988

written statement schedule properties. In that view of the

matter there is no lis between the plaintiffs No.1 and 2 on one

hand and 5th defendant and this defendant on the other hand

and the said settlement has to be recorded by this court. The

defendants No.5 and 6 are bonafide purchasers for valuable

consideration. The defendants No.5 and 6 are entitled to deal

with the properties purchased by them as they choose. There

cannot be any order restraining them from putting up

construction. He admits that Dodda Abbaiah and Chikka

Abbaiah are sons of Late Sidda Reddy. It is not known and

hence not admitted that plaintiffs and defendants are

governed by Hindu Undivided Joint family and suit schedule

properties are all ancestral and joint family properties. It is

true that Dodda Abbaiah died on 28.6.1987 leaving behind

the plaintiffs as his sole surviving legal heirs. It is denied that

Dodda Abbaiah and defendants were managing the schedule

property and after the death of Dodda Abbaiah, defendant

alone is managing the schedule properties. The plaintiffs are

 22 OS No.5985/1988

not entitled to equal share in the half share in the joint family

properties.

 The properties were sold for legal necessities and hence

even if the plaint averments are proved the sale deed in

favour of this defendant is valid. The defendant No.5 got he

property described in item No.1 of the written statement

schedule under sale deed dated 05.07.2006 executed by

Sri.B.N.Chandrashekar and Jayarama Reddy. The vendor of

defendant No.5 purchased the said property from G.Rajashree

under sale deed dated 12.11.2003 and Smt.G.Rajashree got

the same under sale deed dated 18.02.1998 executed by

Chikka Abbaiah. The defendant No.5 is the absolute owner of

the property. However to avoid litigations and to have peace

of mind this defendant got a release deed executed by

plaintiffs No.2 and 3 and as such the suit is liable to

dismissed against the defendant No.5.

 Defendant No.6 got the property described in item No.2

of the written statement schedule under sale deed dated

5.7.2006 executed by Smt.Y.Sumalatha. Said Y.Sumalatha

 23 OS No.5985/1988

purchased the said property from Chikka Abbaiah vide sale

deed dated 20.01.1998. The defendant No.6 is the absolute

owner of the said property. However to avoid litigations and

to have peace of mind this defendant got a release deed

executed by plaintiffs No.2 and 3 and as such the suit is

liable to dismissed against the defendant No.5. Hence,

prayed to dismiss the suit against defendants No.5 and 6 with

respect to written statement schedule item No.1 and 2

properties, which is portion of item No.5 of the suit schedule

property.

 SCHEDULE PROPERTY

 Item No.1: All that piece and parcel of the property

baring Site No.79-3/5, Old katha No.743, New Katha No.79-

3/5 assessment No.912, carved out of converted property

bearing Sy.Nos.79/2 & 79/3 measuring east to west: 50 feet

and north to south: 71 feet, in all measuring 3550 sq.ft.

situated at Bellandur Village, Varthur Hobli, Bangalore East

Taluk (previously called as Bangalore South Taluk) and

bounded on:

 24 OS No.5985/1988

 East by : Site No.76/3/6

 West by : Site Nos.79/3/3 & 79/3/4

 North by : Private property

 South by : Site No.79/3/3 and Road

 Item No.2: All that piece and parcel of the property

baring Site No.79-3/6, Old katha No.744, New Katha No.79-

3/6 assessment NO.913, carved out of converted property

bearing Sy.Nos.79/2 &79/3 measuring east to west: 50 feet

and north to south: 71 feet, in all measuring 3550 sq.ft.

situated at Bellandur Village, Varthur Hobli, Bangalore East

Taluk (previously called as Bangalore South Taluk) and

bounded on:

 East by : Private property

 West by : Site Nos.79/3/5

 North by : Private property

 South by : Site No.79/3/4 and Road

 25 OS No.5985/1988

 11. The defendants No.5 and 6 filed additional written

statement contending that these defendants are not aware of

acquisition of portion of property described in item Nos.2, 4, 6

and 7 by KIADB and the letter referred to in the application

by the LAO. It is not admitted that the amount of

compensable payable has to be shared between plaintiff and

defendants. The defendants have purchased portion of item

No.5 of the suit schedule property. Item No.5 of the suit

schedule property has not been acquired. They denied that

during the pendency of the suit, sites are formed. Hence,

prayed to dismiss the suit.

 12. The defendant No.7 appeared through his counsel,

but did not file his written statement.

 13. On the basis of the above pleadings of both the

parties, the following issues have been framed by my learned

predecessor in office:-

 26 OS No.5985/1988

1) Whether the plaintiffs prove that suit
 properties are the ancestral and joint
 family properties of Dodda Abbaiah and
 defendant?

2) Whether the plaintiffs prove that plaintiffs
 and defendant are in joint possession of the
 suit properties?

3) Do the plaintiffs prove that Dodda Abbaiah
 died in 1987, leaving behind him the
 plaintiffs?

4) Do the plaintiffs prove that they are entitled
 for half share in the entire joint family
 properties?

5) Do the defendant proves that 1st plaintiff
 deserted her husband and walked out of
 his life more than 45 years ago and
 therefore not entitled for share?

6) Whether the defendant proves that item
 No.1 and 3 of the schedule properties are
 his self acquired properties?

7) Whether the defendant proves that his
 brother late Dodda Abbaiah relinquished
 his share in the ancestral properties i.e.
 item 2,4 to 7 in the schedule to plaint,
 about 30 years ago?

8) Whether defendant proves that the suit is
 properly valued?

9) Whether the defendant proves that the suit
 is bad for non-joinder of necessary and
 proper parties, alinee of item 6 has not
 been made as a party to the suit?

10) Whether the plaintiffs prove that they
 are entitled for partition of their half share
 and separate possession of their share in
 all the suit properties?

11) Do the plaintiffs prove that they are
 entitled for mesne profits from the date of

 27 OS No.5985/1988

 suit till the delivery of possession of their
 respective legitimate share in the suit
 properties?

12) What relief or order?

 ADDL. ISSUES

 1) Whether the 2nd defendant proves that
 he has purchased property after
 verifying the representation of 1st
 defendant that he was sole surviving
 male successor to the property?

 ADDL. ISSUES FRAMED ON 14.6.2011

 1) Whether the plaintiffs prove that
 defendants No.1 and 2 have formed sites
 in suit properties as contended by the
 plaintiffs in para 8(a) of the plaint?

 2) Whether the plaintiffs prove that the
 lands in suit item No.2, 4, 6 and 7 were
 acquired by the Karnataka Industrial
 Areas Development Board - KIADB
 Bangalore and the same is the part of the
 subject matter of L.A.C.No.47 of 2007
 pending disposal before the City Civil
 Court, CCH.No.17 as contended by the
 plaintiffs in para -8(b) of the plaint?

 3) Whether the plaintiffs prove that amount
 of compensation in respect of the
 acquired lands will have to be partitioned
 amongst the plaintiffs and the
 defendants, who are entitled to share the
 suit schedule properties as contended by
 the plaintiffs in para 8(c) of the plaint?

 28 OS No.5985/1988

 14. The plaintiffs in order to prove the case have

examined their Special Power of Attorney holder as PW-1 and

got marked seventy four documents at Ex.P.1 to Ex.P.74 and

confronted Ex.D.13 and D.14and examined two witnesses as

PW2 and PW3. The power of attorney holder of legal

representatives 1 and 2 of the 1st defendant examined himself

as DW1 and got marked Ex.D.1 to D.3. The General Power of

Attorney holder of defendant No.2 examined as DW2 and got

marked Ex.D.4 to D.12. The defendant No.6 examined himself

as DW3 and got marked documents at Ex.D.15 to D.24.

 15. Heard the arguments and perused the records of

the case.

 16. My findings to the above issues are as under:

 Issue Nos.1 & 2 : In the affirmative

 Issue No.3 : Partly in the affirmative

 Issue Nos.5 to 7 : In the negative

 Issue No.8 : In the negative

 29 OS No.5985/1988

 Issue No.9 : In the negative

 Addl. Issue No.1 : In the negative
 framed on
 8.9.2000

 Addl. Issue Nos.1 : Do not arise for
 to 3 framed on consideration
 14.6.2011

 Issue Nos.4, 10 to : In the affirmative

 11

 Issue No.12 : As per the final order,
 for the following:

 REASONS

 17. ISSUE No.1 TO 3 AND 5 TO 7:- Since these

Issues are interconnected hence they are taken up together

common discussion in order to avoid repetition of facts and

evidence.

 18. It is admitted fact that Dodda Abbaiah and

defendant No.1 are the direct brothers and sons of Late Sidda

Reddy. It is admitted fact that the 1st plaintiff is the wife of

Dodda Abbaiah. There is no dispute that the said Dodda

 30 OS No.5985/1988

is the case of the 2nd defendant that he is the bonafide
purchaser of item Nos.3 of the suit schedule properties under
the two registered sale deeds dated 12.2.1996 and 31.1.1996
for a valuable consideration and at that time the defendant
No.1 represented him the item No.3 is the ancestral property
of him and the said Dodda Abbaiah and he died issueless and
he was the sole surviving male successor and after
verification purchased it and he is not aware of any legal
proceedings pending.
42. The Defendant No.2 has not entered into the
witness box and thereby failed to prove that he the bonafide
purchaser of item No. 3 of the suit schedule property. Hence
Additional Issue No.1 framed on 08.09.2000 is answered in
the Negative.
43. ADDL. ISSUE NOs.1 TO 3 FRAMED ON
14.6.2011: It is the case of the plaintiffs that defendants No.1
and 2 have formed sites in suit properties and the lands in
suit item No.2, 4, 6 and 7 were acquired by the Karnataka
Industrial Areas Development Board - KIADB Bangalore and
the same is the part of the subject matter of L.A.C.No.47 of
2007 pending disposal before the City Civil Court, CCH.No.17
and the amount of compensation in respect of the acquired
lands will have to be partitioned amongst the plaintiffs and
the defendants, who are entitled to share the suit schedule
properties.
44. The evidence of DW1 shows that sites have been
formed and there is no dispute with respect to acquiring of
item Nos.2, 4 and 7 and depositing of compensation amount
in the court. Hence, these issues have to be considered in the
final decree proceedings. So, I answer Addl. Issues No.1 to 3
framed on 14.6.2011 as do not arise for consideration.
45. ISSUE NO. 4, 10 and 11 : In view of my findings
on Issue No. 1 to 3in the affirmative in favour of the
plaintiffs and Issue No. 5 to 7 in the Negative against the
Defendant No. 1 the plaintiffs are jointly entitle for half
share in all items of suit schedule properties and mesne
profits from the date of the suit till the delivery of possession
of their respective share in the suit schedule properties.
Hence Issue No. 4, 10 to 11 are answered in the affirmative.
46. ISSUE NO. 12: In the result I proceed to pass the
following :
ORDER
Suit of the plaintiffs is decreed.
The plaintiffs are jointly entitled for half
share in the item Nos.1 to 7 of the suit
schedule property.
The plaintiffs are entitled for mesne
profits from the date of the suit till the
delivery of possession of their respective share
in the suit schedule property.
There shall be separate enquiry under

Order 20 Rule 12 of CPC
 with respect to the
mesne profits.
In view of the relationship between the
parties no order as to costs.
Draw preliminary decree accordingly.
